verb.description: Bring into a disordered or confusing state.
examples: I fear he may have muddled the message
they were muddling up the cards

verb.description: Mix (a drink) or stir (an ingredient) into a drink.
examples: muddle the kiwi slices with the sugar

noun.description: An untidy and disorganized state or collection.
examples: the finances were in a muddle
a muddle of French, English, Ojibwa, and a dash of Gaelic

phrases: we don't have an ultimate ambition; we just muddle through
However, I have enough faith in the inherent common sense of the human race to believe that we will, as ever, just manage to muddle through.
I noticed this morning that London Bridge station, after years of muddling through without a logo, has gained one.
Unfortunately, there's no hard and fast guidelines for us to follow - we just have to muddle through, minds fogged by desire.
Those of us who'd been happily muddling along for years and years were faced with a for us or against us ultimatum from the more political of our younger brothers and sisters.
origin: Late Middle English (in the sense wallow in mud): perhaps from Middle Dutch moddelen, frequentative of modden dabble in mud; compare with mud. The sense confuse was initially associated with alcoholic drink (late 17th century), giving rise to busy oneself in a confused way and jumble up (mid 19th century).
